job_title: Main Grade Lecturer in Liverpool, England
pros: Great pay structure and immediate management
cons: Lots of paper trails and unnecessary admin

review_title: Terrible management and support of students in need with EHCP Plans ignored
pros: Working with the students in the class was part of the job. Dependent on what site you were working at higher management varied in the capacity to deal with issues. If you had an issue you could approach but expect kick back. I was given the flexibility to teach what I wanted to teach but you could be teaching them how to boil an egg in an English class for the amount of times I had any support in class.
cons: Where do i start? I could write an excerpt similar to war and peace after my experience. Rampant bullying of staff by higher management who to be fair you have never even met. Just before I left we all had personalised letters regarding attendance of students amounting to bullying tactics. No mention of the sheer incompentence of the progress leaders (nobody knows exactly what they do about from strutting round the building thinking they own it and occasionally find the strength to make a phone call home). You could have reported an issue to progress leaders and ive had emails ignored. Its utterly disgraceful how they manage their own caseload of students. Similarily some of the teaching assistants who had been there years thought they owned the place and where interested in keeping a lid on issues rather than supporting students. There is a culture of 'ive been here years so I can say what i like' regardless of being to be frank not very good at their jobs. I always felt it needed a really good clear out of the dead wood of the TA's. The support of disabled students is clearly an issue in an already stretched support team and this became apparent quite soon after i started 3 years ago. Apparently its ran by someone (manager) who is not even the building and I genuinely never met once in 3 years. I know some students in my classes had dyslexia issues and were still waiting for an assessment almost 18 months after starting the course which is utterly appalling. I know some other students with EHCP Plans that is essentially a legally binding contract not being provided support in class for weeks sometimes several months on end. Bullying is also an issue I know of several colleagues who were bullied by higher management when they decided to honour us with their prescence in a classroom space despite you simply giving 110% in reality towards your teaching and supporting the students. Its not a place for a fulfilled teaching career; its where you go to kill your career and passions for teaching. Its good as a starter to learn the further education system - then move on before it turns you into something you don''t want to be. Pay is absolutely appalling. I could have earnt more working an Amazon warehouse. I am not joking with you.

pros: Improved areas for teaching in practical environments
cons: Negative opinions about teaching staff

pros: Not very many in all honesty
cons: Far too many middle managers

pros: Good pay Flexible staff wellbeing days
cons: 0 hour contract No holiday pay

pros: Students are generally great, staff are mostly fabulous until you get to senior management
cons: Too many to list. Senior management treat staff as worthless and expendable, and students as cash cows. The culture from the top is one of gaslighting and trying to make staff feel they should be grateful for the crumbs from the table while money that should be used to improve the workplace and the student experience is used to create ridiculous new posts for those who toe the party line. Corrupt. Any attempt from the staff to argue for better conditions ends up in valued union reps being dismissed. Staff are beaten down by the atmosphere and the workload and rely on each other to get through the day in the absence of any support from management and in fact often being actively undermined to ensure they stay in line. Long serving staff are forced out or forced onto new contracts which expose them to much worse conditions while the culture of bullying is enforced by promoting those who are happy to continue it.

pros: Location was good, city centre
cons: Little opportunity for career progression

Great colleagues and some really keen students
Good central location
cons:

There is a negative and bullying ethos that comes from the top.

Pay is very poor compared to other institutions

job_title: Main Grade Lecturer in Liverpool, England
pros: For many years this really was the best job in the world. We had a supportive, playful creative environment and morale was very high. Staff were proud to work there and we gained consecutive Outstanding grades from OFSTED. Staff were trusted and respected and the trade union was treated honourably in negotiation
cons:
The catastrophic direction the college then took was signified by principal’s decision to drop the original title of “Community College” (when the priority seemed to staff to shift drastically from genuinely serving the community to what appeared to be simple profit). 

The student experience suffered (in my view) but staff took the brunt of the changes in management attitude. OFTED grades quickly crashed from Grade 1 to a disastrous Grade 4 and observations of teaching and learning went from once every two years (if there were no immediate problems identified) to 6 times a year. This policy was unworkable. 

This twelve-fold increase in scrutiny was a clear indicator that staff were no longer to be trusted but implicitly blamed for the OFSTED collapse since the change in “leadership”. It poisoned good will and devastated morale but was only one very damaging element in a far larger change in attitude.  

For me, a caustic atmosphere of bullying eventually led to a breakdown in any meaningful communication with line management. By this stage local and senior management often exemplified the nasty and unreasonable bullying attitude the college had taken since the current principal took over. 

Staff experience in all areas was one of frequent rounds of “transformation” (redundancy)  with spiralling workloads, frozen pay, belligerent responses to our union and the apparent weaponization of observation systems to target staff in completely unsupportive and demoralising ways. The college was haemorrhaging long standing experienced staff and all the years of dedication that went with that, (particularly as union reps who challenged this seemed to be loosing their jobs at a shocking level). 

The grievance procedures were ineffective, communication was hierarchical and one way, listening to staff concerns was extremely rare and many of us considered that our positions were made untenable. 

The level of stress and damage to wellbeing after decades of faithful service cannot be forgiven. This became a genuinely atrocious workplace and although I miss the students I would never consider returning.

job_title: Main Grade Lecturer in Liverpool, England
pros: The college has always supported staff with training and wellbeing since day one. They have always provided us with new state of the art technology and amazing working environments. The staff I work with are professionals in their own fields. They are supportive, sharing, kind and caring to all and go above and beyond to make you feel welcome. The new management are lovely people, who do everything they can to support all staff in a fair and equal way. I would advise anyone wanting to develop a professional career in any field to consider working at the City of Liverpool College
cons: Teaching in general is becoming tough and fast paced. Keeping up to date with any field with new emerging technology has to be a passion, not a job. If you don’t want to up-skill and maintain professionalism you’re in the wrong job. Yes it’s hard work, long hours and you have a duty of care for your students. Yes, government and educational policy adds to our work load, but the college is trying its best to provide us with training and time to complete this.

pros: Hard working colleagues and great students
cons: Bullying behaviour of senior management

review_title: Great colleagues, Terrible management and work ethics.
job_title: Full Time Lecturer in Liverpool, England
pros: Staff at lecturer levels work hard, Students are unique and quirky.
cons:
Managers - Head of school up wards (They will treat you like crap and throw you under the bus if it makes them look better)  

Principle treats college like an enterprise and misuses money, Some of the higher management do not have the needed knowledge / experience to train staff efficiently.

No advertisement provided unless you're dance, GCSE, or Food.

You're promoted to continue to develop your education but when you do, told to forget it as it's not important.

pros: My colleagues were amazing. Most of the teaching staff are extremely dedicated and supportive.
cons: Management thinks that bullying is perfectly acceptable. Instead of supporting staff, management will make life unbearable in an effort to push you out.

pros: Some of the staff that I work with are dedicated and trying their hardest to keep standards high and create an enjoyable learning experience for students.
cons: Compared to other establishments I have worked in there is an awful lot of 'box ticking' for the sake of having evidence and I have seen these admin tasks detract from quality teaching and learning e.g. Subject tutors are responsible for chasing Math and English absence under the guise of 'personal tutor' following admin staff cuts. Under-staffed (some tutors are teaching 2 different levels of their subject at the same time). Under-resourced (staff are regularly spending their own money on resources after being told there is no more budget). Staff are stretched to much and then expected to perform outstanding. Un-realistic 'targets' e.g. held accountable for student attendance as a part of performance reviews but this is not something staff can fully control and therefore be 100% accountable for. Bullying/aggressive management styles e.g. language, overloading timetables, lack of flexibility/compassion/understanding for use of Toil, timetabling staff over their contracted hours without their consent. Non-progressive in terms of admin (some tasks are triplicated), staff development (CPD) lacks differentiation, student opportunity could be more progressive e.g. more computers, more in class support staff. Too much emphasis on clinically evidencing staff development (new electronic CPD system) rather than actually investing in opportunities for staff and holistically developing them.
